pages.sentence: I write a note to Mia. I start my sentence with a capital letter.
pages.readingTip: Sentences start with a capital letter.

ui.imagePrompt: Simple note card with a capital letter highlighted, calm.

pages.sentence: A statement ends with a period. A question ends with a question mark.
pages.readingTip: Pick the right end mark.

ui.imagePrompt: Two sentence strips labeled statement and question with end marks.

pages.menuStory: What end mark will you use?

ui.imagePrompt: Three punctuation cards: period, question mark, exclamation mark.

pages.question: What ends a question?
pages.passage: A question ends with a question mark.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find the end mark name.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A question ends with a question mark.

pages.question: Which word needs a capital letter?
pages.passage: I write to Mia on May 5.
pages.comprehensionHint: Names and months start with capital letters.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Mia is a name. Names start with capitals.

pages.question: What starts a sentence?
pages.passage: I start my sentence with a capital letter.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find what I start with.

pages.question: What ends a statement?
pages.passage: A statement ends with a period.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find the end mark for a statement.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A statement ends with a period.

pages.question: What ends an exclamation?
pages.passage: An exclamation shows strong feeling and ends with an exclamation mark.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find what shows strong feeling.
pages.successMessage: Yes! An exclamation mark shows strong feeling.

pages.sentence: A noun is a person, a place, or a thing.
pages.readingTip: Find the naming word.

ui.imagePrompt: Three icons labeled person, place, thing.

pages.sentence: Mia is a proper noun. A dog is a common noun.
pages.readingTip: Names are proper nouns.

ui.imagePrompt: Name tag Mia and a dog icon, simple and calm.
Three noun-type cards.

pages.sentence: Mia's hat is red.
pages.readingTip: A possessive noun shows who has something.

ui.imagePrompt: Hat with a name tag Mia, calm.

pages.question: Which word is a noun?
pages.passage: The dog runs.
pages.comprehensionHint: A noun is a person, place, or thing.

pages.question: Which noun is a proper noun?
pages.passage: Mia is a proper noun.
pages.comprehensionHint: A proper noun is a name.

pages.question: Which word shows who has something?
pages.passage: Mia's hat is red.
pages.comprehensionHint: Look for the word with 's.

pages.question: Which word is a place noun?
pages.passage: The park is big.
pages.comprehensionHint: A place is where you can go.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Park is a place noun.

audio.style: clear one vs many, verb matching

pages.sentence: One cat runs. Two cats run.
pages.readingTip: One uses runs. Two uses run.

ui.imagePrompt: One cat vs two cats with matching verb labels.

pages.menuStory: Match the noun and the verb.

ui.imagePrompt: Three count cards: one, two, many.

pages.question: Two cats ____.
pages.passage: Two cats ____.
pages.comprehensionHint: Two means more than one. Use run.

pages.question: One cat ____.
pages.passage: One cat ____.
pages.comprehensionHint: One means one. Use runs.

pages.question: Which noun is plural?
pages.passage: Two cats run.
pages.comprehensionHint: Plural means more than one.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Cats means more than one.

pages.question: The dogs ____.
pages.passage: The dogs jump.
pages.comprehensionHint: Dogs is plural. Use jump without s.

pages.sentence: Mia has a kite. She flies it.
pages.readingTip: A pronoun can take the place of a noun.

ui.imagePrompt: Mia flying a kite; the word She highlighted.

pages.sentence: Two kids have backpacks. Their backpacks are blue.
pages.readingTip: Their shows who has something.

ui.imagePrompt: Two kids with matching backpacks; their highlighted.
Three pronoun cards: I, she, they.

pages.sentence: Give the ball to me. Give it to them.
pages.readingTip: Use me and them after words like to or for.

ui.imagePrompt: Ball being passed to someone; me and them highlighted.

pages.question: Which word is a pronoun?
pages.passage: She flies it.
pages.comprehensionHint: A pronoun can take the place of a noun.

pages.question: Which word shows who has something?
pages.passage: Their backpacks are blue.
pages.comprehensionHint: Find the word that tells whose.
pages.successMessage: Nice! Their is a possessive pronoun.

pages.question: Which pronoun can replace Mia?
pages.passage: Mia has a kite. She flies it.
pages.comprehensionHint: Look at the second sentence. Which pronoun means Mia?

pages.question: Which is correct?
pages.passage: Give the ball to me.
pages.comprehensionHint: After to, use me not I.

pages.question: Which pronoun fits?
pages.passage: I see them at the park.
pages.comprehensionHint: After see or with, use them.
pages.successMessage: Nice! Them is correct after see.

pages.sentence: Yesterday I walked. Today I walk. Tomorrow I will walk.
pages.readingTip: Past, present, future.

ui.imagePrompt: Simple timeline with yesterday, today, tomorrow.

pages.menuStory: Time words help you choose the verb tense.

ui.imagePrompt: Three time cards: yesterday, today, tomorrow.

pages.question: Which verb tells past time?
pages.passage: Yesterday I walked.
pages.comprehensionHint: Past time often ends with ed.

pages.question: Which words tell future time?
pages.passage: Tomorrow I will walk.
pages.comprehensionHint: Future time often uses will.
pages.successMessage: Nice! Will walk tells future time.

pages.question: Which verb tells present time?
pages.passage: Today I walk.
pages.comprehensionHint: Present time is now.

pages.question: Yesterday we ____.
pages.passage: Yesterday we played.
pages.comprehensionHint: Yesterday is past. Use played with ed.

pages.question: Tomorrow I ____ to school.
pages.passage: Tomorrow I will go to school.
pages.comprehensionHint: Tomorrow is future. Use will go.
pages.successMessage: Nice! Will go tells future time.

pages.sentence: This big dog runs.
pages.readingTip: This is a determiner. Big is an adjective.

ui.imagePrompt: Big dog with the words this and big highlighted in different colors.

pages.sentence: My red hat is new.
pages.readingTip: Adjectives describe. Determiners point or tell whose.

ui.imagePrompt: Red hat with the words my and red highlighted.

pages.sentence: I see a dog. The dog is happy.
pages.readingTip: Use a for any one. Use the for a specific one.

ui.imagePrompt: First a dog, then the same dog identified as the dog.

pages.menuStory: A determiner comes before a noun.

ui.imagePrompt: Three determiner cards: this, my, many.

pages.question: Which word is an adjective?
pages.passage: My red hat is new.
pages.comprehensionHint: An adjective describes a noun.

pages.question: Which word is a determiner?
pages.passage: This big dog runs.
pages.comprehensionHint: A determiner points to a noun.

pages.question: Which word is a determiner?
pages.passage: My red hat is new.
pages.comprehensionHint: A determiner tells whose or which one.

pages.question: Which word points to any dog?
pages.passage: I see a dog.
pages.comprehensionHint: A means any one, not a specific one.

pages.question: Which determiner tells how many?
pages.passage: I see many cats.
pages.comprehensionHint: Many tells how many cats.
pages.successMessage: Nice! Many is a determiner that tells how many.

pages.sentence: I like apples and bananas.
pages.readingTip: A conjunction joins words or ideas.

ui.imagePrompt: Two fruit with a plus sign and the word and highlighted.

pages.sentence: I sit on the bench.
pages.readingTip: A preposition tells where.

ui.imagePrompt: Child sitting on a bench with the word on highlighted.

pages.sentence: I like sun but I need rain.
pages.readingTip: But joins two ideas that are different.

ui.imagePrompt: Sun and rain with the word but between them.

pages.menuStory: Is it a conjunction or a preposition?

ui.imagePrompt: Three category cards.

pages.question: Which word is a conjunction?
pages.passage: I like apples and bananas.
pages.comprehensionHint: A conjunction joins words.

pages.question: Which word is a preposition?
pages.passage: I sit on the bench.
pages.comprehensionHint: A preposition tells where.

pages.question: Which sentence has a preposition?
pages.passage: I sit on the bench.
pages.comprehensionHint: A preposition tells where or when.

pages.question: Which conjunction shows contrast?
pages.passage: I like sun but I need rain.
pages.comprehensionHint: But joins different ideas.

pages.question: Which conjunction tells why?
pages.passage: I run because I am late.
pages.comprehensionHint: Because tells the reason.

pages.question: Where is the cat?
pages.passage: The cat sits under the table.
pages.comprehensionHint: Under tells where the cat is.

pages.question: Which shows direction?
pages.passage: I go to school.
pages.comprehensionHint: To shows where you are going.
pages.successMessage: Nice! To is a preposition showing direction.

pages.sentence: I have a dog and I have a cat.
pages.readingTip: And can join two ideas.

ui.imagePrompt: Dog and cat with the word and linking them.

pages.sentence: Where is my hat? Please sit down.
pages.readingTip: Questions ask. Commands tell.

ui.imagePrompt: Two sentence strips: a question and a polite command.

pages.sentence: Wow! I love this game!
pages.readingTip: An exclamation shows strong feeling and ends with !

ui.imagePrompt: Excited child with exclamation marks.

pages.menuStory: What kind of sentence is it?

ui.imagePrompt: Three sentence-type cards.

pages.question: Which is a question?
pages.passage: Where is my hat?
pages.comprehensionHint: A question asks and ends with a question mark.

pages.question: Which sentence is compound?
pages.passage: I have a dog and I have a cat.
pages.comprehensionHint: A compound sentence can join two ideas with and.

answers.name: I have a dog and I have a cat.

pages.correctAnswerName: I have a dog and I have a cat.

pages.question: Which is a command?
pages.passage: Please sit down.
pages.comprehensionHint: A command tells you to do something.

pages.question: Which is an exclamation?
pages.passage: Wow! I love this game!
pages.comprehensionHint: An exclamation shows strong feeling.

pages.question: Which word joins the two ideas?
pages.passage: I have a dog and I have a cat.
pages.comprehensionHint: Look for the word that connects the ideas.
pages.successMessage: Nice! And joins two simple sentences.

pages.sentence: I write the date: May 5, 2025.
pages.readingTip: Use a comma in a date.

ui.imagePrompt: Calendar and a date written with a comma, simple.

pages.sentence: I write a list: apples, bananas, and pears.
pages.readingTip: Use commas to separate items in a list.

ui.imagePrompt: Simple grocery list with commas, calm.
Three choice cards: date, list, both.

pages.question: Where is the comma used?
pages.comprehensionHint: Look at the date. Find the comma.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A date can use a comma.

pages.question: What is being listed?
pages.passage: I write a list: apples, bananas, and pears.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find the items in the list.
pages.successMessage: Nice! You found the list items.

pages.question: How many items are in the list?
pages.passage: I write a list: apples, bananas, and pears.
pages.comprehensionHint: Count the items. Use commas and and to help.

pages.question: Which date is written correctly?
pages.passage: I write the date: May 5, 2025.
pages.comprehensionHint: Use a comma between the day and year.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Put a comma after the day.

pages.question: Which list is written correctly?
pages.passage: I write a list: apples, bananas, and pears.
pages.comprehensionHint: Use commas to separate items.

pages.question: Which sentence needs commas?
pages.passage: I like dogs, cats, and fish.
pages.comprehensionHint: Lists need commas between items.

answers.name: I like dogs, cats, and fish.

pages.correctAnswerName: I like dogs, cats, and fish.

pages.sentence: I use sight words to help me spell.
pages.readingTip: Some words are spelled the same every time.

ui.imagePrompt: Word cards with a pencil, calm.

pages.sentence: I listen to sounds to spell a new word.
pages.readingTip: Say the word slowly. Hear each sound.

ui.imagePrompt: Sound waves leading into letter tiles.

pages.sentence: Words with the same pattern sound alike: cat, bat, hat.
pages.readingTip: Look for patterns like -at, -an, -op.

ui.imagePrompt: Three words in -at family with pattern highlighted.

pages.sentence: Words with the same pattern sound alike: cat, bat, hat.
pages.readingTip: Look for patterns like -at, -an, -op.

ui.imagePrompt: Three words in -at family with pattern highlighted.
Three spelling strategy cards.

pages.question: Which word is spelled correctly?
pages.passage: went
pages.comprehensionHint: Look carefully. Which spelling looks right?

pages.question: Which word is spelled correctly?
pages.passage: cat
pages.comprehensionHint: Listen for c a t.

pages.question: Which word is spelled correctly?
pages.passage: I listen to sounds to spell a new word.
pages.comprehensionHint: Listen for d o g.

pages.question: Which word has the same pattern as cat?
pages.passage: Words with the same pattern sound alike: cat, bat, hat.
pages.comprehensionHint: Look for the -at pattern.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Bat has the -at pattern like cat.

pages.question: Which word is spelled correctly?
pages.passage: I use sight words to help me spell.
pages.comprehensionHint: The is a sight word. Remember how it looks.

pages.question: Which word follows the -an pattern?
pages.passage: I can spell: can, man, pan.
pages.comprehensionHint: Listen for c-an, m-an, p-an.

pages.question: Which word has the same pattern as cat?
pages.passage: Words with the same pattern sound alike: cat, bat, hat.
pages.comprehensionHint: Look for the -at pattern.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Bat has the -at pattern like cat.

pages.question: Which word is spelled correctly?
pages.passage: I use sight words to help me spell.
pages.comprehensionHint: The is a sight word. Remember how it looks.

pages.question: Which word follows the -an pattern?
pages.passage: I can spell: can, man, pan.
pages.comprehensionHint: Listen for c-an, m-an, p-an.

l_v1_context_word_parts.name: Meaning From Context and Word Parts

pages.sentence: The playful puppy runs and jumps all day.
pages.readingTip: Use the sentence to figure out what playful means.

ui.imagePrompt: Happy puppy running and playing.

pages.sentence: She was happy. Then she was unhappy.
pages.readingTip: Un at the start means NOT.

ui.imagePrompt: Two faces: happy then sad, with un- highlighted.

pages.sentence: I jump. I am jumping now.
pages.readingTip: The ending ing means doing it now.

ui.imagePrompt: Person mid-jump with -ing highlighted.

pages.sentence: The root word help is in helping, helped, and helper.
pages.readingTip: Find the root word to know the meaning.

ui.imagePrompt: Word tree showing help with different endings.

pages.menuStory: How can you figure out a word?

ui.imagePrompt: Three strategy cards.

pages.question: What does playful mean?
pages.passage: The playful puppy runs and jumps all day.
pages.comprehensionHint: What does the puppy do? That shows playful.
pages.successMessage: Yes! You used the sentence clue.

pages.question: What does un mean in unhappy?
pages.passage: She was happy. Then she was unhappy.
pages.comprehensionHint: Un changes happy to the opposite.

pages.question: What does ing mean in jumping?
pages.passage: I jump. I am jumping now.
pages.comprehensionHint: The ending ing tells when it happens.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Ing means doing it now.

pages.question: What is the root word in helper?
pages.passage: The root word help is in helping, helped, and helper.
pages.comprehensionHint: Look for the smallest word that makes sense.
pages.successMessage: Nice! Help is the root word.

pages.question: What does redo mean?
pages.passage: I will redo my work. I will do it again.
pages.comprehensionHint: Use the second sentence as a clue.
pages.successMessage: Great! You used context and the prefix re!

pages.sentence: I can sort words into groups. A group can be colors or foods.
pages.readingTip: Groups help you organize words.

ui.imagePrompt: Three baskets labeled Colors, Foods, Animals.

pages.successCriteria: Student sorts each card into the correct category.

ui.imagePrompt: Three category cards with simple icons.

pages.sentence: Red is a color. Apple is a food. Dog is an animal.
pages.readingTip: Say why a word belongs in a group.

ui.imagePrompt: Three example cards: red, apple, dog with labels.

pages.question: Which word is a color?
pages.passage: Red is a color.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find the color word.

pages.question: Why does apple belong in a group?
pages.passage: Apple is a food.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. It tells the group name.

pages.question: Which word is an animal?
pages.passage: Dog is an animal.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find the animal word.

pages.sentence: A cozy place feels warm and safe.
pages.readingTip: Think of a place that feels cozy.

ui.imagePrompt: Cozy corner with blanket and pillow, calm.
Three place cards: bed, sink, street.

pages.sentence: A bed can be cozy with a blanket.
pages.readingTip: Use the word in a real-life example.

ui.imagePrompt: Bed with blanket, cozy style.

pages.question: What does cozy mean?
pages.passage: A cozy place feels warm and safe.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. It tells the meaning.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Cozy means warm and safe.

pages.question: Which place can be cozy?
pages.passage: A bed can be cozy with a blanket.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find the cozy place.
pages.successMessage: Nice! Bed is a cozy place.

pages.question: Which makes a place cozy?
pages.passage: A bed can be cozy with a blanket.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Find what helps make it cozy.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A blanket makes a place cozy.

pages.sentence: Curious means you want to know about things.
pages.readingTip: Learn what the word means first.

ui.imagePrompt: Child looking at something with wonder.

pages.question: What does curious mean?
pages.passage: Curious means you want to know about things.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. It tells the meaning.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Curious means want to know.

pages.question: Which shows being curious?
pages.passage: Curious means you want to know about things.
pages.comprehensionHint: Think about what curious people do.

pages.sentence: Look, peek, and stare are all ways to see.
pages.readingTip: Some words mean almost the same thing.

ui.imagePrompt: Three eye icons showing different looking intensity.

pages.sentence: Peek is quick. Look is longer. Stare is very long.
pages.readingTip: Order the words from weakest to strongest.

ui.imagePrompt: Timeline showing peek, look, stare with arrows.

pages.sentence: Tiny, big, and gigantic are all size words.
pages.readingTip: Words can show different amounts.

ui.imagePrompt: Three objects: ant, box, elephant showing size.

pages.sentence: Tiny is smallest. Big is larger. Gigantic is the biggest.
pages.readingTip: Put size words in order from small to big.

ui.imagePrompt: Size ladder: tiny → big → gigantic.

pages.menuStory: Words can be close in meaning.

ui.imagePrompt: Three category cards.

pages.question: Which word means look quickly?
pages.passage: Peek is quick. Look is longer. Stare is very long.
pages.comprehensionHint: Find the word that is quick.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Peek is the quickest way to look.

pages.question: Which word means look the longest?
pages.passage: Peek is quick. Look is longer. Stare is very long.
pages.comprehensionHint: Find the strongest word.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Stare is the longest way to look.

pages.question: Which word means the smallest?
pages.passage: Tiny is smallest. Big is larger. Gigantic is the biggest.
pages.comprehensionHint: Find the word for the smallest size.

pages.question: Which word means the biggest?
pages.passage: Tiny is smallest. Big is larger. Gigantic is the biggest.
pages.comprehensionHint: Find the strongest size word.

pages.question: Put these in order from smallest to biggest.
pages.passage: Tiny is smallest. Big is larger. Gigantic is the biggest.
pages.comprehensionHint: Think about the size order.
pages.successMessage: Perfect! You ordered the words by size.

pages.sentence: Gentle means soft and kind.
pages.readingTip: Learn the meaning first.

ui.imagePrompt: Definition card for gentle with soft colors.

pages.sentence: I pet the cat with gentle hands.
pages.readingTip: Use the new word in a sentence.

ui.imagePrompt: Child gently petting a cat, calm.

pages.prompt: Use the word gentle in your own sentence.
pages.successCriteria: Student builds a sentence using the target word (parent check if needed).

ui.imagePrompt: Three sentence choice cards, simple.

pages.question: What does gentle mean?
pages.passage: Gentle means soft and kind.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. It tells the meaning.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Gentle means soft and kind.

pages.question: Which sentence uses gentle correctly?
pages.passage: I pet the cat with gentle hands.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. Gentle fits with hands.

answers.name: I pet the cat with gentle hands
I pet the cat with loud hands
I pet the cat with hot hands

pages.correctAnswerName: I pet the cat with gentle hands
pages.successMessage: Nice! That sentence uses gentle correctly.

pages.sentence: Brave means you are not afraid.
pages.readingTip: Learn the meaning first.

ui.imagePrompt: Lion standing tall, confident.

pages.sentence: The brave kid helps the lost dog.
pages.readingTip: Use the new word in a sentence.

ui.imagePrompt: Child helping scared dog.

pages.question: What does brave mean?
pages.passage: Brave means you are not afraid.
pages.comprehensionHint: Read the sentence. It tells the meaning.

pages.question: Which sentence uses brave correctly?
pages.passage: The brave kid helps the lost dog.
pages.comprehensionHint: Think about what brave people do.

answers.name: The brave kid helps the dog

pages.correctAnswerName: The brave kid helps the dog
